page.title: 09]The village stocks
page.content: Standing almost hidden between two huge copper beech trees on the village green are the old stocks. These were made in the time of Elizabeth 1 and were designed so that two malefactors could be seated in them side by side,while a further couple of miscreants could be held by the wrists in the iron clasps on the top of the oak upright. The stocks stood for nearly 300 years to the south of the churchyard and in front of the smithy and were preserved in 1850 by a village carpenter and wheelwright.They were bought and re-erected as a gift from Colonel Lester Reid of Thorpe Mandeville,a member of the Sulgrave Manor Board in 1933.
